qas.question: Who is attributed as first documenting zinc?

qas.question: Why is it possible that the name zinc could be derived from the German zinn?

qas.question: Who is attributed as the only person to document zinc?

plausible_answers.text: metallic zinc crystals have a needle-like appearance

qas.question: Why would zinc possibly be derived from the imaginary word zinke?

plausible_answers.text: Indian tin, tutanego, calamine, and spinter

qas.question: What are some of the other outlawed words for zinc?
What alchemist that first documented zinc was born in India?

context: The name of the metal was probably first documented by <a0_0><b4_0><b7_0>Paracelsus<b7_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, a Swiss-born German alchemist, who referred to the metal as "zincum" or "zinken" in his book Liber Mineralium II, in the 16th century. The word is probably derived from the German zinke, and supposedly meant "tooth-like, pointed or jagged" (<a1_0><b5_0>metallic zinc crystals have a needle-like appearance<b5_0/><a1_0/>). Zink could also <a2_0>imply "tin-like"<a2_0/> because of its relation to German zinn meaning tin. Yet another possibility is that the word is derived from the Persian word سنگ seng meaning stone. The metal was also called <a3_0><b6_0>Indian tin, tutanego, calamine, and spinter<b6_0/>.
